sect2.title: 81 A Practical Guide to the Taxonomy, Classification, and Characterization of Clinically Important Viruses
sect2.para: This chapter was initiated after the first wave of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic in the late summer of 2020 and was written several years after another similar ASM publication (1). The direction of this chapter was influenced after talking to people who were directly impacted by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) but seemed to describe that virus as a stealthy creature that planned its next move based on our reactions in science and medicine. Some key questions that general society has struggled with since late 2019 are, “What are viruses?”, “Where do viruses emerge from?”, and “How much havoc can viruses create in our health care systems and general societies?”. The answer is that although viruses are a diverse and complex group of living entities, their primary focus is to deliver genetic information into human hosts, where that genetic information can be replicated. Even in a modern society with vaccines, antivirals, and advanced medical systems, viruses are often misunderstood. This chapter focuses on the characterization, classification, and taxonomy of viruses that infect humans, both pathogens that infect humans alone and those that infect humans but may also infect other mammalian or nonmammalian genera and species.

sect3.title: DEFINING TAXONOMY
sect3.para: Taxonomy is defined as an approach to arranging viruses into related clusters, defining relatedness within and between clusters, and naming clusters or taxa (2). Classification is defined as the process of determining characters, features, or variables that allow a virus to be placed into a taxonomic system. Characterization is defined as a more granular series of processes where specific characters (e.g., factors, features, or variables, as described below) are identified, further allowing a virus to be assigned within a structured taxonomy. Instead of considering exercises to establish taxonomy, characterization, and classification as a dry, remote academic exercise, these are activities that allow scientists to respond to newly emergent viruses with new diagnostics and therapies or preventive approaches (3). Taxonomy prevents real-world confusion as it creates a common language and allows us to describe viral agents to each other. Very early in the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic, taxonomy allowed scientists to describe a newly emerging virus as a betacoronavirus related to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 1 (SARS-CoV-1) as well as some seasonal beta coronaviruses.

sect3.title: ORIGINS OF VIRUSES
sect3.para: Due to their simple diversity, scientists often struggle with how to classify viruses and occasionally may even question if they belong in the tree of life as living organisms (4). However, viruses exhibit some common attributes shared by other living organisms, including (i) maintenance of a structural organization, (ii) the ability of genomes and gene products to produce progeny genomes, (iii) the possession of self-regulation, and (iv) the ability to adapt and respond to changing environments (5).

Of the two main theories on the origins of viruses, the first suggests that viruses may be remnants of cellular organisms that emerged from cellular hosts and evolved novel replication processes. The second theory suggests that viruses are older than cellular organisms, appearing some time before the emergence of the last universal cellular ancestor (6). Regardless of how viruses originally emerged in this world, it is clear that once viruses emerge or re-emerge in a human population, they coevolve with us and other hosts and vectors (7). As this chapter progresses and the taxonomic diversity of viruses is described, we should remember that all viruses interact with humans through a reductionist commonality: they are all relatively simple genetic information delivery systems for introduction into and replication within our cells (8).

sect3.title: CLASSIFYING VIRUSES ON THE BASIS OF GENETIC CODES AND GENOMES
sect3.para: Viruses are classified or assigned taxa using variables, descriptors, and/or characters (e.g., isolation details, morphology, and physical properties). Molecular characteristics such as nucleic and/or protein sequence homology, genome organization, and replication strategies play an important role in this characterization. For example, the familyPolyomaviridae can be characterized as nonenveloped small viruses that have circular double-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA genomes) (Table 1). Polyomaviridae nucleic acid replication is bidirectional from a unique origin, while protein translation involves early and late transcripts, alternative splicing, and alternative open reading frames (9). On a more reductionist level, molecular phylogenetics investigates evolutionary relationships by comparing molecular (e.g., nucleic acid or protein) sequences and allows comparison of molecular sequences and inferences of relatedness even in the absence of an animal infection model, a virus culture system, or substantial clinical information (10). These approaches are more thoroughly discussed in other chapters but may involve different approaches that may or may not rely on direct sequence alignment (11–13).

sect3.para: The genetic information encoded by viruses is stored, packaged, and delivered through a variety of approaches. This diversity of approaches may provide support for the theory that viruses are polyphyletic (i.e., they have originated from multiple emergence events) and continue to develop along multiple evolutionary pathways. This diversity in how viruses encode their genetic information is described in greater detail inFig. 1 and Tables 1 to 7. At the gene level, this diversity is evidenced by a lack of common genes shared by all viruses (4).

While other forms of life encode genetic information within double-stranded DNA (dsDNA), viruses encode their genetic information within genomes that may be composed of single-stranded RNA (ssRNA), dsRNA, ssDNA, and dsDNA. Virus genomes can also exist in a variety of different topologies, including linear, circular, single segment, or multiple segments, with each architectural form of the viral genome having its own evolutionary benefits and drawbacks (14, 15).

The composition of these genomes impacts the substitution and mutation rates associated with viral evolution. For example, ssRNA viruses generally have the highest mutation rates, followed by retrotranscribing viruses, ssDNA viruses, and dsDNA viruses. These trends in mutation rates cannot be overgeneralized; when substitution rates are expressed as substitutions/site/year, there may be considerable rate variation among RNA viruses (16) as well as an overlap in substitution rates between ssRNA and ssDNA viruses (17). In the natural world, variables that can affect virus genome substitution and or mutation include genomic architecture, replication speed, viral enzymes, host enzymes, and environmental effects such as generation time, transmission, and selection (17).

We can understand the variety of factors impacting a virus genome by using the example of the hepatitis B virus DNA genome. This genome has a relatively low level of mutations compared to other reverse-transcribing viruses while having a mutation rate higher than that of other DNA viruses. Factors proposed to impact the mutation rate of the hepatitis B virus DNA genome include a reverse transcription step, multiple open reading frames (ORFs) that overlap, a reverse transcription (RT) step, and a stable covalently closed circular DNA reservoir. Hepatitis B virus genotype as well as transmission bottlenecks and the length of the infectious process (i.e., chronic versus acute) can all impact the mutation rates of hepatitis B virus (18).

sect3.title: A SHIFT TO WHOLE-GENOME CHARACTERIZATION OF VIRUSES
sect3.para: Molecular classification may be impacted by the molecular target chosen to define taxa, whether it be amino acids sequenced, genes sequenced, core genome, or hypervariable regions of a genome. For example, classification by nucleotide sequences may be biased with saturated substitutions; however, these may be controlled for by using Bayesian methods or maximum-likelihood methods or by analyzing aligned amino acid sequences (19). Use of amino acid analysis alone does not consider noncoding regions, which may be useful in identifying genetic heterogeneity (20). A shift away from the use of partial sequences to classify viruses is expected as barriers to full genome sequencing and managing bioinformatics are reduced (21). However, current taxonomy still provides high-level classification with single genes, including those encoding HK97-fold capsid (the Duplodnaviria members Caudovirales and Herpesvirales), RNA-dependent RNA polymerases (RdRps), RNA-directed DNA polymerases (RdDps) (Riboviria, which includes RNA viruses), replication initiator proteins from the His-hydrophobic-His (HUH) superfamily (single-stranded DNA viruses), and vertical jelly-roll capsid proteins (double-stranded DNA viruses within the real Varidnaviria) (22).

sect3.para: Compared to partial-genome (e.g., single-gene or -region) analysis, whole-genome analysis inherently identifies a greater diversity of variants and genetic relationships within a viral population (19, 23–26). Whole-genome sequencing can be used to identify recombination events within a species (e.g., herpes simplex virus 1 [HSV-1] [Human alphaherpesvirus 1]) as well as recombination events between species (HSV-1 to HSV-2 [Human alphaherpesvirus 1 to Human alphaherpesvirus 2]) (27, 28). Next-generation sequencing approaches are expected to play an increasing role in the taxonomic classification of viruses as access to the technology improves (29) and bioinformatics bottlenecks are eliminated (30–32). In 2016, an International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) workshop titled “Metagenomic Sequencing and Its Impact on Virus Classification” was held. The workshop led to the creation of a consensus document, “Virus Taxonomy in the Age of Metagenomics” (33, 34), which proposed that metagenomic approaches could be used to infer biological properties, which could then be combined with sequence relatedness data and any other biological information. Potential barriers to this approach include mixed virus populations in specimens, mapping of sequences from multipartite/segmented genomes, and virus-derived sequences already integrated into host genomes (33). However, solutions to barriers are developing quickly and may include deep learning approaches to identify viral sequences (35), and new classification approaches to manage metagenomic data and support taxonomic characterization (36).

sect3.title: THE BALTIMORE AND LESS USED APPROACHES TO VIRAL CLASSIFICATION
sect3.para: The taxonomic grouping of viruses uses a variety of defined characters (Fig. 1; Tables 1 to 7). The Baltimore classification, a nonhierarchical approach, categorizes viruses into seven groups and is based on the genome present in virions and type of replication (37, 38). The groupings are as follows: group I, double-stranded DNA viruses; group II, single-stranded DNA viruses; group III, double-stranded RNA viruses; group IV, positive-sense single-stranded RNA viruses; group V, negative-sense single-stranded RNA viruses; group VI, positive-sense single-stranded RNA viruses replicating through a DNA intermediate; and group VII, double-stranded DNA viruses replicating through a single-stranded RNA intermediate (39, 40). Although the Baltimore classification is an older classification system and does not address some details (e.g., the ambisense nature of the genome of the genus Phlebovirus) (Table 5), it does align with classifying genomic sequences using more modern bioinformatics and whole-genome sequence-based approaches (40–42).

Older classification methods not described in detail in this chapter may still be practically applied on a daily basis. As climate change occurs and viral vector (e.g., arthropod) distribution also shifts, we may learn lessons from other systems such as the Holmes classification, an early hierarchical classification approach from the 1940s for insect viruses. That method classified viruses on the basis of the host insect population, the nature of inclusions (or lack thereof) within insect cells, morphology, and disease processes (43). The Lwoff, Horne, and Tournier (LHT) system, which describes viral physical characteristics (e.g., presence or absence of a membrane envelope) (44), can provide a basic practical framework for planning to disinfect a health care setting surface or considering how to pathogen-reduce a blood product.

sect3.title: THE INTERNATIONAL COMMITTEE ON TAXONOMY OF VIRUSES
sect3.para: The ICTV was created for four main purposes: (i) the development of agreed-upon taxonomy for viruses, (ii) the development of agreed-upon names for virus taxa, (iii) communication of taxonomic decisions to the international virology community, and (iv) maintenance of an index of agreed-upon names for virus taxa (45). Since 1971, nine reports have been released by the ICTV as printed books. Historically, this group decided to use species to classify viruses along with genus and family and set about to create working groups to develop plans to demark these species within a hierarchy. The ninth report identified six orders, 87 families, 19 subfamilies, 349 genera, and 2,284 virus and viroid species. However, the tenth report (an online report) created 15 hierarchical ranks with the intent of creating a system that “that closely aligns with the Linnaean taxonomic system” (46). The ranks, from higher to lower, were as follows: realm > subrealm > kingdom > phylum > subphylum > class > subclass > order > suborder > family > subspecies > genus > subgenus > species (46). As with the ninth report, there was no formal classification of viruses below the species rank, although discussion about classification below the species level does occur (e.g., hepatitis E virus, described later in the chapter) (47, 48). The updated species master list is available at the ICTV website (49), and within that master list, the ICTV suggested that there are 4 realms, 9 kingdoms, 16 phyla, 2 subphyla, 36 classes, 55 orders, 8 suborders, 168 families, 103 subfamilies, 1,421 genera, 68 subgenera, and 6,590 species (49, 50). To place this into perspective, in 2021, while we faced a COVID-19 pandemic, the descending hierarchical taxonomy of SARS-CoV-2 was realm Riboviria, kingdom Orthornavirae, phylum Pisuviricota, class Pisoniviricetes, order Nidovirales, suborder Cornidovirineae, family Coronaviridae, subfamily Orthocoronavirinae, genus Betacoronavirus, subgenus Sarbecovirus. That subgenus contains a species identified as Severe acute respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus, which in itself contains the sister clades SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2 (51).

sect3.para: Recently, the ICTV developed a rapid-renewal approach, which means that updates are online and/or are published on their website. Updates to reports are intended to occur in 3-year cycles, with continual changes, summaries, and discussions being published in theJournal of General Virology (52) and more in-depth profiles at the ICTV website (53).

sect3.title: THE ICTV DEFINITION OF A VIRAL SPECIES
sect3.para: The definition of what constitutes a viral species has been a point of contention for decades, with definitions being predominantly based on both the polythetic concept (sharing of multiple characteristics but descended from multiple ancestors) and the monophyletic concept (sharing of a common ancestor) (54). In 1995, the sixth report of the ICTV defined a viral species as a “polythetic class of viruses that constitutes a replicating lineage and occupies a particular ecological niche” (55). By the early 2010s, there was a shift to defining a species as a “monophyletic group of viruses whose properties can be distinguished by multiple criteria” (e.g., genetic characteristics, antigenicity, cell/tissue tropism, natural/experimental host cell range, pathogenicity, and mode of transmission) (56). Although genetic characterization is predominately focused on linking viruses by homology to a “type genomic sequence” (57), the definition of species takes into account other variables, such as gene flow/exchange (58) and genetic characterization approaches (59, 60).

sect3.title: RECENT CHANGES IN VIRAL TAXONOMY TO THE LEVEL OF SPECIES
sect3.para: Between 2016 and 2021, a series of changes have occurred in the taxonomy of viruses that infect humans. In the familyTogaviridae, genus Alphavirus, the species O’nyongnyong virus was renamed Onyong-nyong virus (Table 4).

Several key changes were made in the familyFlaviviridae. Within the genus Flavivirus, the species St. Louis encephalitis virus was renamed Saint Louis encephalitis virus (Table 4). Within the genus Hepacivirus, the species Hepatitis C virus was renamed Hepacivirus C (61, 62).
In the orderMononegavirales, family Filoviridae, genus Ebolavirus, the species Taï Forest ebolavirus was renamed Tai Forest ebolavirus (Table 5).

Multiple changes occurred within the new orderBunyavirales. Within the family Hantaviridae, multiple species, including Hantaan orthohantavirus, Andes orthohantavirus, Seoul orthohantavirus, and Sin Nombre orthohantavirus, were moved from the genus Hantavirus to the genus Orthohantavirus. Within Orthohantavirus, 24 new species were created (63) (Table 5); these changes are described below. Within the family Nairoviridae, the genus Nairovirus (which contained the species Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever nairovirus) was changed to Orthonairovirus (e.g., Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever orthonairovirus) (Table 5). A new family, Phenuiviridae, was created and this includes the genus Phlebovirus and its species Rift Valley fever phlebovirus (type), Naples phlebovirus, and Sicilian phlebovirus (Table 5) (64).

Multiple name changes were made within the orderMononegavirales, family Paramyxoviridae (Table 5). Within the subfamily Orthoparamyxovirinae, genus Henipavirus, the species Hendra virus and Nipah virus were changed to Hendra henipavirus and Nipah henipavirus (65). Within the subfamily Orthoparamyxovirinae, genus Morbillivirus, the species name Measles virus was changed to Measles morbillivirus (Table 5). Within the subfamily Orthoparamyxovirinae, genus Respirovirus, the species Human parainfluenza virus 1 and Human parainfluenza virus 3 were changed to Human respirovirus 1 and Human respirovirus 3, respectively (Table 5). Within the subfamily Rubulavirinae, genus Orthorubulavirus, the species Human parainfluenza virus 2 and Human parainfluenza virus 4 were changed to Human orthorubulavirus 2 and Human orthorubulavirus 4, respectively. Within the same genus, the species name Mumps virus was changed to Mumps orthorubulavirus. Within the family Pneumoviridae, genus Orthopneumovirus, the species name Respiratory syncytial virus was changed to Human orthopneumovirus (61).

sect3.title: VIRAL CLASSIFICATION BELOW THE LEVEL OF SPECIES
sect3.para: Classification of viruses below the level of species is not standardized across all species by the ICTV, but in some cases, subspecies standardization does occur. For example, within the speciesSevere acute respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus, as new isolates are identified, the ICTV suggests the naming individual isolates “SARS-CoV-2/host/location/isolate/date” (51). The paramyxovirus Nipah virus (NiV) can be divided into two strains, Malaysia (NiVM) and Bangladesh (NiVB), with NiVB being potentially more pathogenic than NiVM (66). For rotaviruses, the ICTV has proposed that strains be named “RV group/species of origin/country of identification/common name/year of identification/G- and P-type” (67). Dengue virus can be subdivided into five serotypes (DENV1 to -5), which may vary in terms of disease and epidemiologic patterns (68, 69). For example, in Singapore, DENV-1 was more likely to be associated with dengue hemorrhagic fever than DENV-2 (70).

sect3.title: WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION GUIDANCE ON CLASSIFYING HUMAN INFECTIOUS DISEASES
sect3.para: In 2015, the World Health Organization (WHO) released its “Best Practices for the Naming of New Human Infectious Diseases” (71). These naming practices were developed for use in the following types of novel diseases: (i) a human infection, syndrome, or disease, (ii) a disease not previously recognized in humans, (iii) a disease exhibiting potential public health impact, and (iv) a disease with no common established name. This best practice document also identified guidelines for novel disease naming that considered generic descriptors (e.g., clinical symptoms or systems affected), specific descriptor terms (e.g., seasonality and severity), and other associated descriptors (e.g., year and arbitrary identifier). In 2020, the WHO named the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2 “COVID-19,” an abbreviation of “coronavirus disease 2019” (72). The final point made by the WHO was that the intention of these guidelines was not to impact the naming conventions of the current International Classification of Diseases (ICD) system (73).

sect3.title: CLASSIFYING VIRUSES AND VIRAL DISEASES USING THE ICD SYSTEM
sect3.para: The ICD is a WHO-developed standardized tool created to organize and code mortality and morbidity data to support primary care/treatment, statistics, research, epidemiology, and health care management and delivery. ICD codes can be used to characterize the general health of a country or population, including the impact of viruses on individual and population morbidity/mortality (74). In 2018, the WHO released the 11th version of ICD codes (ICD-11) which followed a 10th revision (ICD-10), which was originally released in 1990 (75, 76). The 2020 English version of ICD-11 is available online; it allows easy searching of viral diseases, syndromes, and viruses themselves and is supported by a user guide (77). Upgrades in ICD-11 were intended to reflect changes in science and technology, utilize improvements in our understanding of disease treatment and prevention, document more meaningful clinical content, and improve the ease and accuracy of coding (78, 79).

Within ICD-11, an alphanumeric coding system is used to classify diseases that are caused by a variety of factors, including infectious diseases caused by viruses (Tables 1 to 7) (77). Under code 01, “Certain infectious or parasitic diseases,” one of the classifiers is “Viral hepatitis” which includes an infection with one or more of the following viruses: hepatitis A virus, hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus, hepatitis D virus, and hepatitis E virus (77). This classification excludes herpes simplex hepatitis (1F00) and does not include “viral hepatitis complicating pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium” (JB63.4) or “Congenital viral hepatitis” (KA62.9). The codes for acute hepatitis are as follows: acute hepatitis A, 1E50.0 (which excludes “Infectious liver disease” [DB90] and “Acute or subacute hepatic failure” [DB91]); acute hepatitis B, 1E50.1; acute hepatitis C, 1E50.2; acute hepatitis D, 1E50.3; and acute hepatitis E, 1E50.4. Other codes for acute hepatitis include cytomegaloviral hepatitis, 1D82.0, other specified acute viral hepatitis, 1E50.Y, and other specified acute viral hepatitis, 1E50.Y.

ICD codes (e.g., ICD-10 and/or ICD-11) are forms of administrative health data that can provide insight into the population impact of viral diseases but may lack sensitivity to classify disease, including new illnesses such as COVID-19 (80). In one study, ICD-10 codes missed nearly 60% of influenza diagnoses in a pediatric hospital setting (81). However, these issues with the sensitivity of administrative codes in characterizing diseases or pathogens may be pathogen or disease specific. For dengue virus morbidity, ICD-10 codes have been shown to have high sensitivity and moderate specificity compared to chart review (82). Another study indicated that ICD-10 codes had high specificity but moderate sensitivity for hepatitis C virus and hepatitis B virus infections (83). As described earlier, the new ICD-11 system was designed to describe clinical presentations more effectively than ICD-10. For example, although the ICD-10 system had codes for Marburg virus disease (MVD; A98.3) and Ebola virus disease (EVD; A98.4), it did not provide a definition of the disease or the spectrum of its manifestations (84).

Tables 1 to 7 summarize the clinically important viruses and link these viruses to ICD-11 codes and associated disease processes. The intention is not to exhaustively describe the clinical relevance of each virus but to provide examples of how these viruses can be further organized. In some cases (Tables 1 to 7), a virus may be a definite cause of an illness but may not have an ICD-11 organism code or be directly linked to a disease in an ICD-11 search. For example, Usutu virus may be linked to 1C80 (viral encephalitis) but not classified elsewhere. Other disease processes listed by ICD-11 may appear to be linked to a genus but may not be specifically linked to all species of a genus. For example, human T-cell lymphotropic virus-associated myelopathy (code 8A45.00) is linked to Primate T-lymphotropic virus 1 (human T-lymphotropic virus 1 [HTLV-1]) but not Primate T-lymphotropic virus 2 (human T-lymphotropic virus 2 [HTLV-2]) (Table 6) (85, 86). Other secondary disease processes may also be described, sometimes as footnotes. For example, Human orthopneumovirus (human orthopneumovirus, human respiratory syncytial virus, and XN275 human respiratory syncytial virus) can be linked to the specific code CA40.11 (“Pneumonia due to Respiratory syncytial virus”) as well as the nonspecific code CA00 (“Acute nasopharyngitis”).

In some cases, a virus genus or species may be putatively associated with an ICD-11 code and a disease process but may not currently fulfill Koch’s postulates. For example,Banna virus may be a cause of tick-borne encephalitis (XN0L1, “Tick-borne encephalitis virus: possible association”) (Table 3) (87). Cosavirus A may be possibly associated with intestinal infection (1A2Z, “Viral intestinal infections, unspecified: possible association”), especially in immune compromised and pediatric patients (88). While Chandipura vesiculovirus (Chandipura virus) has recently emerged as a human pathogen associated with viral encephalitis outbreaks (1C80, “Viral encephalitis not elsewhere classified”) (Table 5) (89, 90), Isfahan vesiculovirus (Isfahan virus) is not strongly associated with human disease.

sect3.title: SPECIFIC CHANGES IN APPROACHES TO VIRAL TAXONOMY
sect3.para: The following are examples of recent specific changes in taxonomic approaches that have led to changes in classification, ranging from subspecies to higher-level classification.

sect2.title: Hepatitis E (Orthohepevirus A) Subtype Reference Sequences: Classification Below the Species Level
sect2.para: The seven genotypes of hepatitis E virus (HEV-1 to HEV-7) are situated within the familyHepeviridae and genus Orthohepevirus. The species Orthohepevirus A contains five genotypes that infect humans (HEV-1, -2, -3, -4, -7, and -8). Other animal hosts for these genotypes include pigs (HEV-3 and -4), rabbits (HEV-3), wild boars (HEV-3 and -4), mongoose (HEV-3), deer (HEV-3), yaks (HEV-4), and camels (HEV-7) (91, 92). Human infections may arise from vertical transmission, drinking contaminated water, animal exposure, eating contaminated meat (e.g., raw pork), and blood transfusion (91, 92). Currently, the assignment of a new genetic sequence to a genotype is based on comparisons of ORF-1 and ORF-2 amino acid sequences (93, 94). The assignment of new HEV sequences to a genotype can be hampered by a lack of agreement on subtype reference sequences and a lack of consistent criteria for determining intra- and intersubtype distances. To allow the comparison of results between epidemiologic and clinical case studies and to reduce the risk of HEV misclassification, the ICTV has proposed a standard reference set of complete genome sequences (48).

sect2.title: Hantaviruses (Orthohantavirus) Reclassified and Reorganized
sect2.para: Between 2016 and 2020, there were several changes that impacted the taxonomy of the hantaviruses. As briefly described above, the genusHantavirus was changed to Orthohantavirus and the hantaviruses were assigned to the family Hantaviridae (order Bunyavirales) (Table 5). Changes in species demarcation criteria led to the creation of 24 new species and the abolishment of seven species. A subset of Orthohantavirus species including representative common names are listed in Table 5, with a full listing in the ICTV Master Species List (49). Species demarcation was based on the following factors: multiple alignment coding-complete regions of amino acids within the nucleocapsid protein (small [S] segment) and glycoproteins (medium [M] segment), calculated pairwise evolutionary distance (PED) values, and determination of a species at a specific PED cutoff (95). The following seven species were removed or identified as strains of other defined species with the reasons provided: Isla Vista hantavirus (incomplete sequence data), Muleshoe hantavirus (incomplete sequence data), New York hantavirus (high amino acid homology to Sin Nombre orthohantavirus M and S segments), Rio Mamore hantavirus (high sequence amino acid homology to M and S segments of Laguna Negra orthohantavirus), Rio Segundo hantavirus (incomplete sequence data), Saaremaa hantavirus (high sequence homology to Dobrava-Belgrade orthohantavirus), and Topografov hantavirus (high similarity to Khabarovsk orthohantavirus) (95, 96).

sect2.title: Species Demarcation of Arenaviruses (genus Mammarenavirus)
sect2.para: The arenaviruses are situated within the genusMammarenavirus, which along with three other genera are within the family Arenaviridae and order Bunyavirales (Table 5) (97). Traditionally, antigenic properties have been used to divide the mammarenaviruses into either New World mammarenaviruses (e.g., Tacaribe serocomplex [Americas]) or Old World mammarenaviruses (e.g., the Lassa-lymphocytic choriomeningitis serocomplex [Africa]). Further division of the New World mammarenaviruses uses nucleoprotein (NP) sequences to create clades A, B, and C (97–99). More recently, genus demarcation was based on pairwise sequence comparisons (PASC) of coding-complete genomes including sequences within S segments and large (L) segments, or when a complete genomic sequence for the S segment is available with a cultured isolate and phenotypic information (architecture and antigenicity) is available (100, 101). As a result of these changes in approach, species may be defined by a combination of variables, including transmission patterns, host range, geographic location, pathobiology, sequence homology cutoffs in S and L segments, and NP amino acid sequence identity (101). Changes in approaches to speciation meant that some viruses were relocated to formal species (e.g., Junín virus to Argentinian mammarenavirus and Sabiá virus to Brazilian mammarenavirus) (100).

sect2.title: Changing Approaches to Classifying Astroviruses (Mamastrovirus)
sect2.para: Historically, the familyAstroviridae within the order Stellavirales was divided into two genera based on hosts (e.g., Mamastrovirus [mammals] and Avastrovirus [birds]) (102). Prior to 2010, serotyping was used to distinguish five serotypes of human astroviruses, with further work identifying eight human astrovirus serotypes (103). By 2010, an approved proposal from the ICTV Astroviridae Study Group classified mamastroviruses based on the complete amino acid sequence of the ORF2 genome region encoding the viral capsid (104). As shown in Table 4, the classic eight serotypes of human astroviruses are situated within the species Mamastrovirus 1. A novel group of astroviruses (MLB 1 to 3) were classified within Mamastrovirus 6. Yet another group of novel astroviruses (HMO [human, mink, and ovine-like astroviruses]) were classified into Mamastrovirus 8 and Mamastrovirus 9 (103). One issue complicating classification, as new genomic sequences are identified, is that there are a limited number of ORF2 amino acid sequences available to guide classification (103). There may also be recombination events in the ORF1b and ORF2 regions of parental strains that create recombinants from classic human and nonhuman parental strains (105).

sect3.title: CONCLUSION
sect3.para: Viruses are a complex group of organisms that have diverse origin stories and face multiple unique evolutionary pressures. Their interaction with humans during the infection process leads to various host and pathogen outcomes, which also impact how viruses evolve over time. Our use of constructs such as characterization, classification, and viral taxonomy allow us to assess the risks that viruses pose to humans, enable us to respond quickly to emerging pathogens, and ensure that we have a common language for the sharing and integration of newly acquired knowledge. As a result, not only can new and emergent viruses such as SARS-CoV-2 find a place in the “tree of life” relatively quickly, but also, researchers may be able to move quickly to use preexisting knowledge generated from work on other viral relatives to assess risks of human-to-human transmission, understand potential patient outcomes, and create new diagnostic assays or vaccines. Since 2019, there have been significant changes in the field of viral taxonomy with the creation of new taxonomic classifications (e.g., realms), changes in names of genera, and the reassignment of commonly named viruses into new formal species. Although these changes can be confusing, they represent the rapid pace of change in medical virology brought on by new genetic sequencing approaches, approaches to bioinformatics, new phylogenetic approaches, and insights by the researchers working on these agents. Over time, we can expect taxonomic resources to change and become more complex as they move online and are edited in a more real-time manner. We should expect to see more vibrant discussion on the taxonomy of viruses as our knowledge of these agents grows exponentially over the next decade.
